Module Basics
Package basics.math

Class Matrix

java.lang.Object
basics.math.Matrix
public class Matrix
extends java.lang.Object
Matrix computations and solving linear equations (also overdetermined). The matrixes are defined as double[][], whereas the first index defines the row, the second the column (i.e. the [0] is the array of the first row). The constants vector is defined as double[]. To solve, e.g. 
 x*1+y*2=100
 x*5-y*10=30
The corresponding code is: 
    double[][] mat=new double[][]{
      {1.0,   2.0 },
      {5.0, -10.0 }
    };
    double[] constants=new double[] {
      100.0,
      30.0
    };
    double[] res=solveLinearEquation(mat,constants);
After this, res[0]=x, res[1]=y. The core methods (invert, gaussian) were found at http://www.sanfoundry.com/java-program-solve-linear-equation/
Author:
Jörg Roth (Joerg.Roth@Wireless-earth.org)

      public static double det​(double[][] matrix)

      Parameters:

      Returns:

    • reflection

      public static double[] reflection​(double[] vector, double[] normal)

      Reflect a direction vector at a surface, defined by a normal. The reflected direction is returned. An arbitrary dimensionally reflection can be computed – vector and normal must be of the same dimension.

      The formula for
      • original vector vorg
      • reflection vector vrefl
      • normal n
      • scalar procuct scalar(a, b)
      vrefl=vorg-2·scalar(vorg,n)·n.
      Parameters:
      vector - direction vector
      normal - surface's normal
      Returns:
      reflected direction vector.

    • homogeneousMatrixFromDenavitHartenbergParameters

      public static double[][] homogeneousMatrixFromDenavitHartenbergParameters​(double theta, double d, double a, double alpha)
      Create a 4x4 homogenous roto-translation matrix from Denavit-Hartenberg parameters. The parameters assume a transformation of reference systems xi-1, yi-1, zi-1 to xi, yi, zi, wheras
      • each zi is along the motion axis, i.e., the rotation axis of rotation joint or the moving axis of sliding joint,
      • xi is perpendicular both to zi-1 as well as to zi,
      • xi intersects both zi-1 as well as zi,
      • yi forms a right-handed coordinate system with xi, zi.
      Parameters:
      theta - joint-angle θ: rotation around zi-1 to align xi-1 to xi
      d - joint distance d: translation along zi-1 to get to the intersection of zi-1 and xi
      a - arm length a: translation along xi to map zero point i-1 to zero point i
      alpha - torsion angle α: rotation around xi to align zi-1 to zi
      Returns:
      4x4 matrix

    • rotationMatrix2D

      public static double[][] rotationMatrix2D​(double sina, double cosa)
      Computes a rotation matrix 2x2. sin and cos of the angle are given. Positive angles turn counter-clockwise.
      Parameters:
      sina - sin(angle)
      cosa - cos(angle)
      Returns:
      2x2 rotation matrix

    • angleFromRotationMatrix2D

      public static double angleFromRotationMatrix2D​(double[][] matrix)
      Compute the angle for a rotation matrix. Some tests are executed to check, if the matrix really is a rotation matrix. After executing this code 
       double[][] rot=Matrix.rotationMatrix2D(Math.sin(ang),Math.cos(ang));
 double ang2=Matrix.angleFromRotationMatrix2D(rot);
      ang and ang2 are equal (mod multipier of 2·Π)
      Parameters:
      matrix - a rotation matrix
      Returns:
      rotation angle

    • rotationMatrix3DX

      public static double[][] rotationMatrix3DX​(double sina, double cosa)

      Computes a rotation matrix 3x3 for rotation about x axis. sin and cos of the angle are given. If we look onto the y/z-plane on a right-handed coordinate system (x-axis points to observer) positive angles turn counter-clockwise.

      This methods holds the following relations to the Rodrigues rotation matrix method:

      Matrix.rotationMatrix3DX(Math.sin(ang),Math.cos(ang)); is equal to Matrix.rotationMatrix3DRodrigues(ang,1,0,0);
      Parameters:
      sina - sin(angle)
      cosa - cos(angle)
      Returns:
      3x3 rotation matrix

    • rotationMatrix3DY

      public static double[][] rotationMatrix3DY​(double sina, double cosa)

      Computes a rotation matrix 3x3 for rotation about y axis. sin and cos of the angle are given. If we look onto the x/z-plane on a right-handed coordinate system (y-axis points away(!) from observer) positive angles turn counter-clockwise.

      This methods holds the following relations to the Rodrigues rotation matrix method:

      Matrix.rotationMatrix3DY(Math.sin(ang),Math.cos(ang)); is equal to Matrix.rotationMatrix3DRodrigues(ang,0,-1,0);
      Parameters:
      sina - sin(angle)
      cosa - cos(angle)
      Returns:
      3x3 rotation matrix

    • rotationMatrix3DZ

      public static double[][] rotationMatrix3DZ​(double sina, double cosa)

      Computes a rotation matrix 3x3 for rotation about z axis. sin and cos of the angle are given. If we look onto the x/y-plane on a right-handed coordinate system (z-axis points to observer) positive angles turn counter-clockwise.

      This methods holds the following relations to the Rodrigues rotation matrix method:

      Matrix.rotationMatrix3DZ(Math.sin(ang),Math.cos(ang)); is equal to Matrix.rotationMatrix3DRodrigues(ang,0,0,1);
      Parameters:
      sina - sin(angle)
      cosa - cos(angle)
      Returns:
      3x3 rotation matrix

    • rotationMatrix3D

      public static double[][] rotationMatrix3D​(double sinAngXY, double cosAngXY, double sinAngXZ, double cosAngXZ)
      Computes a rotation matrix 3x3 for rotation about two axes:
      • first in the x-y plane
      • then in the x-z plane
      sin and cos of the angle are given.
      Parameters:
      sinAngXY - sin(angle in the x-y plane)
      cosAngXY - cos(angle in the x-y plane)
      sinAngXZ - sin(angle in the x-z plane)
      cosAngXZ - cos(angle in the x-z plane)
      Returns:
      3x3 rotation matrix

    • rotationMatrix3Dreverse

      public static double[][] rotationMatrix3Dreverse​(double sinAngXY, double cosAngXY, double sinAngXZ, double cosAngXZ)
      Computes a rotation matrix 3x3 for rotation about two axes:
      • first in the x-z plane
      • then in the x-y plane
      (note, this is reverse to rotationMatrix3D(double,double,double,double). sin and cos of the angle are given.
      Parameters:
      sinAngXY - sin(angle in the x-y plane)
      cosAngXY - cos(angle in the x-y plane)
      sinAngXZ - sin(angle in the x-z plane)
      cosAngXZ - cos(angle in the x-z plane)
      Returns:
      3x3 rotation matrix

    • rotationMatrix3D

      public static double[][] rotationMatrix3D​(double sinAngXY, double cosAngXY, double sinAngXZ, double cosAngXZ, double sinAngYZ, double cosAngYZ)
      Computes a rotation matrix 3x3 for rotation about three axes:
      • first in the x-y plane
      • then in the x-z plane
      • finally in the y-z plane
      sin and cos of the angle are given.
      Parameters:
      sinAngXY - sin(angle in the x-y plane)
      cosAngXY - cos(angle in the x-y plane)
      sinAngXZ - sin(angle in the x-z plane)
      cosAngXZ - cos(angle in the x-z plane)
      sinAngYZ - sin(angle in the y-z plane)
      cosAngYZ - cos(angle in the y-z plane)
      Returns:
      3x3 rotation matrix

    • rotationMatrix3DReverse

      public static double[][] rotationMatrix3DReverse​(double sinAngXY, double cosAngXY, double sinAngXZ, double cosAngXZ, double sinAngYZ, double cosAngYZ)
      Computes a rotation matrix 3x3 for rotation about three axes in reverse order compared to rotationMatrix3D(double,double,double,double,double sinAngYZ,double), i.e.
      • first in the y-z plane
      • then in the x-z plane
      • finally in the x-y plane
      sin and cos of the angle are given.
      Parameters:
      sinAngXY - sin(angle in the x-y plane)
      cosAngXY - cos(angle in the x-y plane)
      sinAngXZ - sin(angle in the x-z plane)
      cosAngXZ - cos(angle in the x-z plane)
      sinAngYZ - sin(angle in the y-z plane)
      cosAngYZ - cos(angle in the y-z plane)
      Returns:
      3x3 rotation matrix

    • rotationMatrix3DRodrigues

      public static double[][] rotationMatrix3DRodrigues​(double alpha, double gx, double gy, double gz)
      Computes a rotation matrix 3x3 for rotation. The Rodrigues approach is used, that describes a rotation with
      • the unit vector of the rotation axis
      • a single angle to rotate about this vector
      If g points to the observer positive angles turn counter-clockwise. This methods holds the following relations to the other rotation matrix methods
      • Matrix.rotationMatrix3DX(Math.sin(ang),Math.cos(ang)); is equal to Matrix.rotationMatrix3DRodrigues(ang,1,0,0);
      • Matrix.rotationMatrix3DY(Math.sin(ang),Math.cos(ang)); is equal to Matrix.rotationMatrix3DRodrigues(ang,0,-1,0);
      • Matrix.rotationMatrix3DZ(Math.sin(ang),Math.cos(ang)); is equal to Matrix.rotationMatrix3DRodrigues(ang,0,0,1);
      Parameters:
      alpha - the rotation angle in radians
      gx - rotation unit vector x
      gy - rotation unit vector y
      gz - rotation unit vector z
      Returns:
      3x3 rotation matrix

    • rotationThatMaps

      public static double[][] rotationThatMaps​(double[] p0, double[] p1)
      Computes a rotation matrix that maps two points. Actually only to directions to points, viewed from the zero-point are considered. It will not be checked, if both points have the same distance to the zero-point.
      Parameters:
      p0 - original point (direction vector from zero-point)
      p1 - mapped point (direction vector from zero-point)
      Returns:
      rotation matrix that maps p0 to p1

    • eulerAngles

      public static double[] eulerAngles​(double[][] rotation)
      Get the Euler angles from a 3x3 rotation matrix, if the rotation is applied in the ordering x-y-plane – x-z-plane – y-z-plane.
      Parameters:
      rotation - rotation matrix
      Returns:
      array of three angles with [0]: angYZ rotation angle in radians in the y-z-plane, [1]: angXZ rotation angle in radians in the x-z-plane [2]: angXY rotation angle in radians in the x-y-plane,

    • eulerAnglesReverse

      public static double[] eulerAnglesReverse​(double[][] rotation)
      Get the Euler angles from a 3x3 rotation matrix, in reverse order (compared to eulerAngles(double[][])), i.e. if the rotation is applied in the ordering y-z-plane – x-z-plane – x-y-plane.
      Parameters:
      rotation - rotation matrix
      Returns:
      array of three angles with [0]: angYZ rotation angle in radians in the y-z-plane, [1]: angXZ rotation angle in radians in the x-z-plane [2]: angXY rotation angle in radians in the x-y-plane,

    • solveLinearEquation

      public static double[] solveLinearEquation​(double[][] a, double[] b)
      Solve a linear equation ax=b for matrix a (square) and constants b.
      Parameters:
      a - matrix a
      b - constant vector b
      Returns:
      variables x

    • solveOverdeterminedLinearEquation

      public static double[] solveOverdeterminedLinearEquation​(double[][] a, double[] b)
      "Solve" an overdetermined linear equation ax=b for matrix a (m>n) and constants b. Note that the result is not actually the solution as usually overdetermined equations do not have any. Instead, the result is the vector that minimizes the square errors. It bases on the approach to solve ATAx=ATb.
      Parameters:
      a - matrix a
      b - constant vector b
      Returns:
      variables x

    • vectorProduct

      public static double[] vectorProduct​(double[] a, double[] b)

      Computes a vector product (cross product) of two vectors, i.e. a×b. Only vectors with 3 dimensions are allowed.

      The motivation: for two vectors in a plane, the normal vector is computed.
      Parameters:
      a - first operand vector
      b - second operand vector
      Returns:
      vector product

    • vectorProductInv

      public static double[][] vectorProductInv​(double[] normal)

      Compute the 'inverse' of the vector product (cross product). As they are an invinite number of vectors that have a certain cross product, only two (arbitrary) representative are returned.

      The motivation: for a normal, compute two vectors that span the plane. I.e.
      • they are right-angled
      • each is right-angled to the normal
      Apart from this, the two vectors are arbitrary vectors. The caller can not rely on any specific rule for any of this vectors.
      Parameters:
      normal - surface normal
      Returns:
      array of 2, each vector x, y, z, each normalized to size 1

    • crossMatrix

      public static double[][] crossMatrix​(double[] a)
      Computes the cross matrix [a]×. The result holds the following equation: [a]×·b=a×b. Only a vector with 3 dimensions is allowed.
      Parameters:
      a - vector
      Returns:
      cross matrix

    • invert

      public static double[][] invert​(double[][] a)
      Invert a square matrix.
      Parameters:
      a - matrix
      Returns:
      inverted matrix

    • pseudoInverse

      public static double[][] pseudoInverse​(double[][] matrix, boolean checkRank)
      Computes an inverse of an n×m matrix, dependent on m, n:
      • m=n: computes the 'normal' inverse
      • m>n: computes the left pseudo inverse
      • m<n: computes the right pseudo inverse
      Parameters:
      matrix - matrix
      checkRank - if true, a (costly) check is performed for a condition, if the rank of the matrix is sufficient. If not checked and the rank was too low, the result is useless, in particular not the pseudo inverse.
      Returns:
      pseudo inverse

    • rightPseudoInverse

      public static double[][] rightPseudoInverse​(double[][] matrix, boolean checkRank)
      Computes the right pseudo inverse, i.e. for a matrix A the Ar with A·Ar=I (with I unit matrix). Typically, the number of columns must be greater than the number of rows to get a right pseudo inverse.
      Parameters:
      matrix - matrix
      checkRank - if true, a (costly) check is performed for a condition, if the rank of the matrix is sufficient. If not checked and the rank was too low, the result is useless, in particular not the pseudo inverse.
      Returns:
      right pseudo inverse

    • leftPseudoInverse

      public static double[][] leftPseudoInverse​(double[][] matrix, boolean checkRank)
      Computes the left pseudo inverse, i.e. for a matrix A the Al with Al·A=I (with I unit matrix). Typically, the number of rows must be greater than the number of columns to get a left pseudo inverse.
      Parameters:
      matrix - matrix
      checkRank - if true, a (costly) check is performed for a condition, if the rank of the matrix is sufficient. If not checked and the rank was too low, the result is useless, in particular not the pseudo inverse.
      Returns:
      left pseudo inverse

    • eigen2x2

      public static double[][] eigen2x2​(double[][] matrix)
      Compute the Eigenvalues and Eigenvectors of a 2 x 2 matrix.
      Parameters:
      matrix - a matrix
      Returns:
      array of 3 with [0]: the two Eigenvalues, [1]: Eigenvector of first Eigenvalue, [2]: Eigenvector of second Eigenvalue

    • symmetricEigenMatrices2x2

      public static double[][][] symmetricEigenMatrices2x2​(double[][] matrix)
      Compute the Eigenvalues and Eigenvectors of a symmetric 2 x 2 matrix. Each symmetric matrix A can be expressed as A=Q·L·QT where Q is a rotation matrix and L contains the λi on the diagonal (0 else). In other words, after executing
        double[][][] eigen=Matrix.symmetricEigenMatrices2x2(matrix);
  double[][] result=Matrix.multiply(eigen[0],eigen[1],Matrix.transpone(eigen[0]));
      result and matrix are equal.
      Parameters:
      matrix - a matrix
      Returns:
      array of 2 with [0]: matrix Q, [1]: matrix L

    • symmetricEigenValues2x2

      public static double[] symmetricEigenValues2x2​(double[][] matrix)
      Compute the Eigenvalues and rotation angle of a symmetric 2 x 2 matrix. Each symmetric matrix A can be expressed as A=Q·L·QT where Q is a rotation matrix and L contains the λi on the diagonal (0 else). This method only returns the λi and the rotation angle of the underlying rotation matrix. In other words, after executing
        double[] eigen=Matrix.symmetricEigenValues2x2(matrix);
  double[][] matrixL=new double[][]{{eigen[0],    0.0d},
                                    {0.0d,    eigen[1]}};
  double[][] matrixQ=Matrix.rotationMatrix2D(Math.sin(eigen[2]),Math.cos(eigen[2]));

  double[][] result=Matrix.multiply(matrixQ,matrixL,Matrix.transpone(matrixQ));
      result and matrix are equal.
      Parameters:
      matrix - a matrix
      Returns:
      array of 3 with [0]: λ1, [1]: λ2, [2]: rotation angle

    • eigen3x3

      public static double[][] eigen3x3​(double[][] matrix)
      Compute the real Eigenvalues and Eigenvectors of a 3 x 3 matrix.
      Parameters:
      matrix - a matrix
      Returns:
      either array of 4 with [0]: the three Eigenvalues, [1]: Eigenvector of first Eigenvalue, [2]: Eigenvector of second Eigenvalue, [3]: Eigenvector of third Eigenvalue or array of 2 with [0]: the one real Eigenvalue, [1]: Eigenvector of the one Eigenvalue

    • ordering

      public static int[] ordering​(double[] vector)
      Compute the ordering of vectors up to 3 elements. The ordering means: a vector represents the index in increasing ordering, e.g. 
       (2.0, 10.0, 1.0) → (1, 2, 0)
 (5.0, 3.0, 1.0) → (2, 1, 0)
 (2.0, 1.0) → (1, 0)
      Parameters:
      vector - a vector with up to 3 elements
      Returns:
      list of same length with indexes
